item.title: Pest control redesign
item.description: Motivation: the nets made it annoying to water the plants, and the beans and tomatoes were getting crowded. I’m a little worried about squirrels jumping from the fence onto the tomatoes though.

item.title: Mysterious Cruciferae
item.description: I completely lost track of which of the cruciferae plants are cabbages, broccoli, or cauliflower. It will be a surprise!

item.title: Cantelope
item.description: Transplanted the cantelope seedlings last night. I hope they do as well as the cucumbers.

item.title: Cucumbers
item.description: The cucumber plants seem to be growing finally. After three unsuccessful attempts to seed them outdoors, seeding them indoors did the trick. It turns out that transplanting them before they developed real leaves doesn’t seem to have been a problem so far, despite the warnings of all the gardening blogs.

item.title: Butternut squash
item.description: Butternut squash looking good. It’s taking a while though. This is five weeks after planting.

item.title: Garden #2
item.description: Garden #2 is finally taking off.

item.title: Green beans
item.description: A handful of beans for dinner. Eight weeks after planting. Next year I will need to plant 4x the number of plants if I want to make a meal out of a single harvest.

item.title: Baby green beans
item.description: The green beans are starting to show themselves!

item.title: Roast beet salad
item.description: Roasted the beets to make a salad for lunch.

item.title: Beets
item.description: It was time to harvest most of the beets.

item.title: Big tomato
item.description: My tomato plant is getting huge!

item.title: Mystery plant
item.description: I haven’t been having so much luck in my second garden. The lettuce, Swiss chard and beans are doing ok, but I also planted cucumber, cantelope, zucchini, butternut squash, cauliflower and cabbage, and nothing seems to be sprouting. Then this little guy showed up. At first I was very excited…but it looks suspicious. Not like any veggie seedling I’ve seen before. I suspect it’s a weed but I’ll give it a few days.

item.title: Pest Control
item.description: When I tried to grow tomatoes a couple of years ago, they all got eaten by mystery visitors. Don’t want to take any chances this time!

item.title: Lettuce
item.description: Tom Thumb lettuce growing nicely. Already harvested many outer leaves for salads.

item.title: Beets
item.description: Beets are coming along nicely. Harvesting lots of greens to saute with the Swiss chard.

item.title: Bean flowers
item.description: I’ve never seen bean flowers before!

item.title: Radishes
item.description: Radishes are upping their game.

item.title: Swiss chard
item.description: Swiss chard ready to be sauted.

item.title: Surprise tomatoes
item.description: Some surprise tomatoes! I wasn’t expecting them so early.

item.title: Spinach
item.description: Spinach at six weeks.

item.title: Swiss chard
item.description: Swiss chard at six weeks.

item.title: Progress
item.description: The garden at six weeks.

item.title: Salad
item.description: Butter lettuce, spinach, and Swiss chard at five and a half weeks.

item.title: Radishes
item.description: Radishes at five weeks. Not much luck…all cracked and nibbled.

item.title: Garden #2 finished
item.description: Finishing the second plot.

item.title: Garden #2 started
item.description: Marking out the second plot.

item.title: Beets at four weeks
item.description: I accidentally planted too many beets, so I had to pull some out to give the others room to grow. At four weeks, it’s all greens and no bulb. But I was happy to throw the greens into a salad.

item.title: Baby Radish
item.description: First harvest from the ground. A radish, four weeks after planting from seed. I think the radishes need some more time. It tasted good though!

item.title: Bean sprouts
item.description: It’s really a bean sprouting!

item.title: After the rain
item.description: Three and a half weeks after first planting. The difference between the two radish crops (bottom-left), which are two weeks apart, is dramatic!

item.title: The full garden
item.description: The full garden.

item.title: First harvest
item.description: Onion greens for our baked potatoes.

item.title: Third planting
item.description: Tomato and parsley seedlings from the eco market. Also planted more carrot and radish seeds, as well as bush bean seeds. The garden is full!

item.title: Wooden border
item.description: I added a wooden border and now it looks like a real garden.

item.title: Something is happening
item.description: Ten days after planting. The radish sprouts (bottom left) are looking great!

item.title: Second planting
item.description: Beets and Swiss chard seeds needed to soak for 24 hours, so they were planted the next day.

item.title: First planting
item.description: Planted radishes, two kinds of lettuce, spinach, and carrots from seed. Planted white and yellow onions from sets.
